thread.title: Margaret Court Arena aces LEED sustainability certification
thread.title_full: Margaret Court Arena aces LEED sustainability certification

author: Philip Hopkins
title: Margaret Court Arena aces LEED sustainability certification
text:
Margaret Court Arena has achieved a major international standard for sustainability.
The Melbourne venue is the first sport and entertainment arena in Australia to receive a LEED Gold certification.
The LEED rating system, developed by the US Green Building Council, covers buildings, homes and communities that are designed, built, maintained and operated to a high environmental performance.
Margaret Court Arena, which was designed and built by Lend Lease, achieved high performance in sustainable site development, water savings, energy efficiency and materials selection.
Advertisement The key initiatives include an operable roof allowing airconditioning and lighting systems to be reduced when conditions are favourable, the reuse of existing structures, sustainably sourced timber, recycling of waste generated in construction, a cool roof that reflects the sun's heat, shading overhangs that block summer sun but allow winter sun, and rainwater-flushed toilets that are connected to the site-wide water harvesting system.
More than 154 countries are participating in LEED, which stands for Leadership in Energy and Environmental Design. To receive the LEED certification, building projects must satisfy prerequisites and earn points to achieve different levels of certification.
The arena was a joint venture between NH Architecture and Populous, while Lend Lease was the managing contractor and builder.
